FacilityName: CF Industries, Inc. Plant City Phosphate Complex

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CF Industries, Inc. is one of North American?s largest interregional cooperatives, owned by and serving 8 regional cooperatives.  Through its Members, the Company?s nitrogen, phosphate and potash fertilizer products reach over a million farmers and ranchers in 48 states and two Canadian provinces.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

     CF Industries, Inc. Plant City Phosphate Complex handles anhydrous ammonia, a commercial chemical that is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Its most extensive use (about 80%) is in soil fertilization as a source of nitrogen, which is essential for plant growth.  The CF Industries, Inc. Plant City Phosphates Complex uses anhydrous ammonia to manufacture of fertilizer products for agricultural use elsewhere.  The Plant City Phosphate Complex has an extensive safety program that assures compliance with all applicable local, state and federal rules and regulations. In fact, the facility operates under a Corporate Policy that endorses going beyond regulatory requirements when necessary to protect the health and safety of its employees and the public.  The design, maintenance and operation of this facility are carried out in compliance with this program and policy to provide a safe operation and to prevent exposure of our employees and the nearby neighbors to ammonia.  

     The Facility?s Emergency Response Plan is based upon OSHA?s hazardous waste operations and emergency response standard [29 CFR 1910.120(q)].  The plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.  Additional response procedures include: HAZMAT trained operating and supervisory personnel, emergency response drills with local emergency responders, ammonia sensors located at critical locations in the process area, continuous monitoring of ammonia sensor readings, continuous recording of weather conditions, and fog nozzles and

other equipment for ammonia suppression. 
 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance  

     The Plant City Phosphate Complex receives shipments of anhydrous ammonia by rail with the rail cars stored at various locations at the plant site until there is space in the seven storage bullets for the rail ammonia.  The ammonia is transferred from the railcars to pressurized ammonia tanks.  The ammonia is pumped from the tanks directly to the four granulation plants, where it is combined with phosphoric acid to produce ammonium phosphate fertilizers.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.  

     The only substance regulated under EPA?s RMP requirements at this facility is ammonia.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps

     The primary purpose of this facility?s Process Safety Management Program (PSM) is to safeguard our employees and nearby neighbors from exposure to ammonia by providing assistance in evaluating and updating the facility?s process and mechanical safety procedures and programs.  This facility?s Process Safety Management Program (PSM) was developed in compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management Rule 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.  

Five Year Accident History

In the past five years, there have been no ammonia releases that caused injury or property damage either on-site or off-site. 
 

Emergency Response Program

HAZMAT training is performed in accordance with OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 (g) and pre-emergency planning and drills have been conducted with outside responders.  The emergency response program conforms to the OSHA Process Safety Management Program as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119.  The HAZMAT team has conducted joint training and drills with the local fire departments.  Facility personnel have conducted meetings informing the public of the facility?s Emergency Response Pro

gram.  The facility uses the Incident Command System that was developed by the National Fire Academy.

The facility installed alarms and a telephone notification system for the community during 1999.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

CF will continue to provide support to and work with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and emergency responders to plan for the appropriate emergency response and to prepare for responding to an emergency through practice and drills.
